posts.name: Prat Prakash
posts.cooked:
For the past couple weeks, we‚Äôve been running a Rio-less system just to tune and test out our cameras and vision setups. This system consists of a PDH, VRM, Radio, and LL2. The limelight was wired to the PDH port with a 10A breaker on it, and has been working fine.

Today, we replaced it with a LL3 (Off of a separate robot where it has worked in the past), and it didn‚Äôt turn on. On further inspection, we realized that there was a slight burning smell from its power ports, and when we put it back onto the robot where we took it off of, it didn‚Äôt turn on there either. Is there any reason this could‚Äôve happened? We made sure not to crosswire anything, and after putting the LL2 back on, it worked fine again.

Any help is appreciated.

posts.name: Vlad B
posts.cooked:
What you did looks exactly like spec . The only thing I can think of is reverse polarity or shorting.

A picture of your setup (if available) would be helpful.

posts.name: Prat Prakash
posts.cooked: One thing that was different between both setups was that due to the testboard not having a Rio, we wired the Limelight‚Äôs ethernet directly to the first ethernet port on the radio, rather than through an ethernet switch. The radio itself was powered through a barrel jack connected to the VRM. Is it possible that we shorted the LL3 by connecting it‚Äôs PoE port to a PoE port on the Radio? There‚Äôs nothing in the limelight documentation warning against this.

posts.name: Vlad B
posts.cooked: That might just be it, as I think you need to wire PoE directly (as the VRM output is too high). Interesting your Limelight 2 was unaffected.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
vladb:

(as the VRM output is too high).

You shouldn‚Äôt wire Limelights to the VRM because the max amperage is too low.

My guess is there was a short in the power.  Was it only powered by the PoE or did you also run power to the LL itself.  If one of the wires gets out of the where you push them in and shorts across it can fry your LL .

Have you contacted limelight support?  They are pretty good about replacing them.

posts.name: Vlad B
posts.cooked:
Bmongar:

You shouldn‚Äôt wire Limelights to the VRM because the max amperage is too low.

(From spec)

Do not use the REV radio power module to power your Limelight. Its output voltage is too high.

Bmongar:

My guess is there was a short in the power

That‚Äôs probably more likely, though I‚Äôm not convinced.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
vladb:

Do not use the REV radio power module to power your Limelight. Its output voltage is too high.

But an RPM isn‚Äôt the CTR VRM .  the CTR VRM output is 12V and the REV RPM is 18V.  The CTR VRM has a 2A max draw where the limelight can draw 7A

posts.name: Vlad B
posts.cooked:
Oh, I see. My apologies. Then that can‚Äôt be an issue.

Short it (probably) is!

posts.name: Gordon Walsh
posts.cooked:
Where did you get the 7A number from? Common instructions say to use a 5A breaker. The numbers we got after asking the manufacturer was 700mA at 12V for a LL2+, and that there shouldn‚Äôt be any issue running it off of a (non-radio) VRM‚Äôs 12V 2A output. AFAIK, the instruction not to use the VRM is more just about being generally unnecessary to regulate the battery power twice and ensuring rules are followed than some bad VRM vibes travelling through the wire and breaking the LL through the power input.

Also, I‚Äôm not sure I understand the suggestion of shorting as a failure mode? Is the claim that one of the main voltage input wires coming out and shorting to the other wire outside of the case is causing internal damage? I‚Äôm not seeing how that is causing internal damage. External scorching or a smell maybe, but complete device failure? Or is the claim that a loose power wire contacted some other connector (which would be much harder on a LL3 than a 1/2/2+ with the relocated power input)? Or a short between some LL outputs (USB power maybe)?

It‚Äôs certainly possible that there was an internal short caused by some metallic debris, but that would be a very different root cause than a problem with the power supply setup. That feels like something that should be fairly well protected against at this price-point and use-case, but I don‚Äôt have all the details of electronics manufacture.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
You are right 5A is the correct number. Which is still more than the 2A of VRM.

We have fried a LL before when a strand from a hot wire touched the ground at the entry point.

posts.name: Taegen P
posts.cooked:
Do you have any setup pictures? It might help discern the exact issue.

Either way I cannot recommend enough that you email LL directly about this. We‚Äôve had issues with limelight‚Äôs of our own and their customer service is top notch.

If you tell them your setup, send some pictures, I have total faith that they will help you get to the bottom of it and make sure it doesn‚Äôt happen again.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
Bmongar:

You are right 5A is the correct number. Which is still more than the 2A of VRM .

The reason 5a breakers are recommended is because that‚Äôs the lowest available breaker for the PDP / PDH . The limelight certainly does not draw 5a continuously.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: A pi cm4 is rated for 1.4 Add something leds and a fan and you can onl go up. The camera would need some power. Then if you put a camera or coral on the USB you need to power that.  2a isn‚Äôt a lot the VRM isn‚Äôt a good choice

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: The cm4 specifies 1.4a at 5v (7W). At 12v (ignoring conversion losses), thats 0.58a. 12v2a is plenty to run a limelight. As said above, the reason limelight recommends powering directly off of the PDP is not because it will cause damage, but because it is redundant.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: So ignoring the LEDs, fan, and any USB peripheral it would run. But leds and the fan are definitely things.

posts.name: Prat Prakash
posts.cooked:
I won‚Äôt be back in the bay until later this week, but i put together this diagram using the TKO Circuit simulator + MS Paint to demonstrate my setup. In this picture, the second ethernet port on the radio is empty.

Problem sc 550√ó711 45 KB

Problem sc 550√ó711 45 KB

On all the other setups where the LL3s were known to work, we plugged them into either an Ethernet switch or the second radio port.

I contacted Limelight on Saturday, but have not heard back from them yet.
